subject: Barclays warns Apple's (AAPL) offer to replace batteries cheaply may cut sales of new iPhones by 16 million this year
DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
4th January 2018

US

FOMC MEETING MINUTES: The Fed’s latest meeting minutes were, on balance, neutral. However, traders seemed to focus on news that a few policymakers noted that median Fed projections published in December would bring too many rate hikes in 2018, but a few others stated that more hikes would be required in 2018 than implied by the projections. Elsewhere, policymakers generally saw medium-term inflation outlook as little changed, though “several” were concerned that persistently weak inflation may have hampered inflation expectations. Despite an initially muted reaction, USD gained strength and gold ebbed lower with markets likely disregarding the fears of ‘too many hikes in 2018’ given the upcoming change in composition at the Fed which many view as having a more hawkish tilt.


EQUITIES

EQUITIES: SPX +0.64% at 2713, DJI +0.4% at 24922, NDX +1% at 6576

Top performers: Energy +1.6%, IT 1.1%, Health Care 1%
Bottom performers: Telecom -2.2%, Utilities -0.7%, Consumer Staples -0%

The S&P 500 opened at a fresh record high on Wednesday, and powered through the 2,700 handle shortly afterwards, building on Tuesday’s record gains.

Gains were lead by the energy complex, which tracked crude prices higher. Tech stocks were also firm after a number of brokerages upgraded the likes of Oracle (ORCL) and IBM (IBM).

However, some of the tech sector’s gains were mitigated by Intel (INTC) with reports suggesting that some of their chips had significant design flaws, although the news buoyed some of its competitors.

Automakers were also performing well on Wednesday, following the monthly sales updates for December, with the big three reporting numbers slightly better than forecast.

On the other end of the scale, telecoms were lagging.

TREASURIES

As on Tuesday, Treasuries were following Bunds in early trade, with curve flattening being seen ahead of the ISM data and FOMC meeting minutes, with real money said to be buying in the long-end. But the Treasury complex ran into sellers after decent ISM Manufacturing data, with 2-year yields rising to a nine-year high.
ASIA-PAC

EU/UK

UK Markit/CIPS Cons PMI (Dec) 52.2 vs. Exp. 52.8 (Prev. 53.1)

 

FX
 

The Dollar got a boost after decent ISM Manufacturing and construction spending. Of particular encouragement was the prices paid sub-component rising strongly, though ahead of this week’s payrolls data, the employment sub-index slipped by 2 points.

The release of the Fed’s December meeting minutes had little immediate impact, though in the aftermath of the release, the dollar found some strength against the yen, but gains against other majors were more muted.

Dollar strength pushed EUR to within 1.20 in wake of the release. The EUR was unable to take advantage of solid German labour market data, and there was little impact from Tuesday’s hawkish comments from ECB’s Nowotny, who echoed the sentiments of ECB’s Coeure over the weekend; the message seems to be that policymakers are becoming comfortable in talking about the end of the central bank’s QE programme in September 2018 if the Eurozone economy continues to progress.

The pound gave back gains made yesterday, falling towards the 1.35 handle; while most of the underperformance was being attributed to the dollar strength, at the margin, a weaker-than-expected construction PMI contributed.

CAD traders were battling around the 1.25 handle once again, on Wednesday. A reported barrier option at 1.2490, however, remained unbreeched, leaving the currency to trade at c.1.2550 ahead of the Fed’s meeting minutes release.

Other commodity FX couldn’t capitalise on higher crude prices: NOK was up by around 0.2% before the release of the Fed’s meeting minutes, though AUD and NZD were flat. The former was said to be capped by offers around 0.7850, and more are said to be lurking ahead of 0.79. While the NZD – which slipped in APAC trade – continued to hold at levels seen overnight.

Firmer risk appetite kept the JPY, CHF and XAU negative ahead of the FOMC’s meeting minutes; after the release, however, the yen weakened further, while gold dropped to $1307, before once again recovering towards $1315.

COMMODITIES

COMMODITIES: WTI futures settle $1.26 higher at $61.63 per barrel; Brent futures settle $1.26 higher at $61.36 per barrel

Continuing tensions in Iran, optimism about the health of the global economy, and expectations that this week’s energy inventory data will see crude stocks falling for the seventh straight week helped the crude complex remain above the closely-watched $60/bbl mark.

Finally, OPEC members supplied 32.47mln BPD in December, according to a newswire poll (Prev. 32.448mln BPD in November), with analysts expecting the Saudis will have cut volumes to 9.95mln BPD, and Libya seeing a fall to 970k BPD. Compliance is expected to remain around 121%.

US API Cushing number (25 Dec, w/e) -2.11M (Prev. 0.07M)

US API weekly dist. stocks (25 Dec, w/e) 4.272M vs. Exp. 1M (Prev. -2.850M)

US API weekly gasoline stk (25 Dec, w/e)  1.87M vs. Exp. 1.9M (Prev. 2.001M)

US MARKET WRAP: fresh record highs for stocks amid mildly hawkish Fed
content:
FOMC MEETING MINUTES

The Fed’s latest meeting minutes were, on balance, neutral. However, traders seemed to focus on news that a few policymakers noted that median Fed projections published in December would bring too many rate hikes in 2018, but a few others stated that more hikes would be required in 2018 than implied by the projections.

Elsewhere, policymakers generally saw medium-term inflation outlook as little changed, though “several” were concerned that persistently weak inflation may have hampered inflation expectations.

Despite an initially muted reaction, USD gained strength and gold ebbed lower with markets likely disregarding the fears of ‘too many hikes in 2018’ given the upcoming change in composition at the Fed which many view as having a more hawkish tilt.

EQUITIES: SPX +0.64% at 2713, DJI +0.4% at 24922, NDX +1% at 6576

Top performers: Energy +1.6%, IT 1.1%, Health Care 1%

Bottom performers: Telecom -2.2%, Utilities -0.7%, Consumer Staples -0%

The S&P 500 opened at a fresh record high on Wednesday, and powered through the 2,700 handle shortly afterwards, building on Tuesday’s record gains.

Gains were lead by the energy complex, which tracked crude prices higher. Tech stocks were also firm after a number of brokerages upgraded the likes of Oracle (ORCL) and IBM (IBM).

However, some of the tech sector’s gains were mitigated by Intel (INTC) with reports suggesting that some of their chips had significant design flaws, although the news buoyed some of its competitors.

Automakers were also performing well on Wednesday, following the monthly sales updates for December, with the big three reporting numbers slightly better than forecast.

On the other end of the scale, telecoms were lagging.

FOREX:

The Dollar got a boost after decent ISM Manufacturing and construction spending. Of particular encouragement was the prices paid sub-component rising strongly, though ahead of this week’s payrolls data, the employment sub-index slipped by 2 points.

The release of the Fed’s December meeting minutes had little immediate impact, though in the aftermath of the release, the dollar found some strength against the yen, but gains against other majors were more muted.

Dollar strength pushed EUR to within 1.20 in wake of the release. The EUR was unable to take advantage of solid German labour market data, and there was little impact from Tuesday’s hawkish comments from ECB’s Nowotny, who echoed the sentiments of ECB’s Coeure over the weekend; the message seems to be that policymakers are becoming comfortable in talking about the end of the central bank’s QE programme in September 2018 if the Eurozone economy continues to progress.

The pound gave back gains made yesterday, falling towards the 1.35 handle; while most of the underperformance was being attributed to the dollar strength, at the margin, a weaker-than-expected construction PMI contributed.

CAD traders were battling around the 1.25 handle once again, on Wednesday. A reported barrier option at 1.2490, however, remained unbreeched, leaving the currency to trade at c.1.2550 ahead of the Fed’s meeting minutes release.

Other commodity FX couldn’t capitalise on higher crude prices: NOK was up by around 0.2% before the release of the Fed’s meeting minutes, though AUD and NZD were flat. The former was said to be capped by offers around 0.7850, and more are said to be lurking ahead of 0.79. While the NZD – which slipped in APAC trade – continued to hold at levels seen overnight.

Firmer risk appetite kept the JPY, CHF and XAU negative ahead of the FOMC’s meeting minutes; after the release, however, the yen weakened further, while gold dropped to $1307, before once again recovering towards $1315.

FIXED INCOME: US 10Y T-Note future settles +3 ticks at 123'25

As on Tuesday, Treasuries were following Bunds in early trade, with curve flattening being seen ahead of the ISM data and FOMC meeting minutes, with real money said to be buying in the long-end. But the Treasury complex ran into sellers after decent ISM Manufacturing data, with 2-year yields rising to a nine-year high.

COMMODITIES: WTI futures settle $1.26 higher at $61.63 per barrel; Brent futures settle $1.26 higher at $61.36 per barrel

Continuing tensions in Iran, optimism about the health of the global economy, and expectations that this week’s energy inventory data will see crude stocks falling for the seventh straight week helped the crude complex remain above the closely-watched $60/bbl mark.

After the bell, the API will release its energy inventory data, and analysts expect to see headline crude stocks draw by 5.3mln barrels. Stocks at Cushing are seen drawing by 2.35mln barrels according to Genscape data. Products, meanwhile, are seen building, with distillates forecast to add 1.0mln barrels to stocks, while gasoline is expected to show a build to 1.9mln barrels.

Traders were also citing data out of Brazil, which showed crude oil output declining by 1.2% in November. And elsewhere, a gas pipeline fire in Nigeria also gave traders reasons to avoid selling in the energy complex, some reported.

Finally, OPEC members supplied 32.47mln BPD in December, according to a newswire poll (Prev. 32.448mln BPD in November), with analysts expecting the Saudis will have cut volumes to 9.95mln BPD, and Libya seeing a fall to 970k BPD. Compliance is expected to remain around 121%.

Despite an initially muted reaction, USD is gaining strength and gold ebbing lower with markets likely disregarding the fears of "too many hikes in '18'' given the upcoming change in composition at the Fed which many view as having a more hawkish tilt

subject: A Turkish banker has been convicted in the US of violating Iranian sanctions
FOMC MINUTES:
content:
- A few policymakers noted that median Fed projections published in Dec would bring too many rate hikes in 2018. A few others stated that more hikes would be required in 2018 than implied by the projections. 

- Policymakers generally saw medium-term inflation outlook as little changed. Several were concerned that persistently weak inflation may have hampered inflation expectations.
reaction_details: - Little seen in the way of a market reaction given the balanced nature of the minutes and upcoming Fed composition changes which could see a shift in the viewpoint of the Fed going forward.

subject: PREVIEW: FOMC Meeting Minutes Preview (Dec 2017)
content:
• The FOMC will release its meeting minutes from the December 2017 meeting on 3 January at 1400 ET (1900 GMT)
• The central bank hiked rates by 25bps in December, and now sees seven hikes over the forecast horizon vs six previously
• Inflation forecasts were unchanged, growth forecasts were raised on account of upcoming fiscal stimulus
• Market reaction may be limited given that the FOMC's voting rotation has changed

FX Daily Wrap: Usd recovery gains foothold, for now at least
content:
DXY

The Index has crept back over the 92.000 level, but it was a slow grind and not really on any specific Dollar positive factors before decent US manufacturing ISM and construction spending data beats. The Greenback has benefited from consolidation elsewhere, as G10 rivals lose some bullish momentum ahead of key chart, psychological and/or other significant levels.

AUD

Bucking the overall retreating trend vs its US peer, Aud/Usd maintained 0.7800+ status, but a good supply of offers around 0.7850 continues to keep a lid on the pair as attention switches to the December Fed minutes.

GBP

Cable ran in to offers around 1.3600 early in the session and Sterling was also undermined by another sub-consensus UK PMI headline read, breaching 1.3500 (just) late on.

EUR

Tested support at 1.2000 vs the Usd after the upbeat US macro releases, but never threatened last year’s 1.2092 best despite a better than forecast German jobs report.

JPY

Marginally extended its downside vs the Dollar as light offers around 112.40 were absorbed, but 112.60-70 could be more resilient given reports of bigger sell orders in that area. On the flip-side, 112.00 and a tad above provides solid support.

CAD/CHF

Both weaker vs the Greenback, with the Loonie unable to build on recent gains to seriously test support through 1.2500 and 1.2490 option barriers despite firmer oil prices, while Usd/Chf almost rebounded to 0.9800.

subject: Fixed Income latest: upside option plays in USTs
content: In keeping with the bullish reversal in bonds some OTM call buying in US Treasuries with the 125.00 strike lifted in the Feb18 expiry for 6 ticks in a cumulative 60k lots. Note, the underlying Mar18 future is around 123-265 and just off the 123-27 intraday peak. Meanwhile, Bunds have pulled back a bit further from best levels, but Gilts continue to inch higher and just traded at 124.89, +77 ticks. Lots of corporate and syndicated sovereign supply in the pipeline, and broadly well sought after.

subject: Ireland's May 2028 size has been set at EUR 4bln
Scana (SCG) announce all stock merger with Dominion (D) in a cash and stock deal value at $7.9bln
Bunds: stops tripped and Tuesday’s Eurex peak taken out
content: Volume stats suggest that buy orders were situated in the mid-161.50 area, and as noted previously the next level on the upside was yesterday’s opening session high at 161.78, which was eclipsed by a few ticks as Bunds traded up to 161.82 before fading relatively rapidly. The price action certainly indicates that stops prompted a more pronounced short squeeze, and Gilts extended their rebound to 124.75 (+53 ticks) before running out of steam almost as quickly/abruptly. Regardless, the core Eurex debt future has reversed all and a bit more of Tuesday’s drop despite bumper investor demand for Ireland’s 10 year syndicated offering and a more emphatic recovery in peripheral paper, with MiFID 2 low turnover exacerbating moves.

subject: Books for Ireland's 2028 bond are now in excess of EUR 14bln; spread set at MS +2bps
Air Berlin (AB1 GY) sells Air Berlin Aviation GMBH to Thomas Cook (TCG LN); value is medium single-digit millions, according to a source
Nigerian power grid has been shut down by a fire on gas pipeline, according to the Ministry of Power
EU DEBT/STIR UPDATE: Liffe leading latest uptick
content: Gilts and Short Sterling have emerged as the front-runners, as bond and rate futures continue to chip away at losses made on the first trading day of 2018. The 10 year UK benchmark just topped out at 124.60 for roughly ½ point bounce from the earlier Liffe base, while the 3 month strip has been 3 ticks ahead vs 1 tick down, with a decent clip bought in the Jun18 contract at 99.350 (6500 lots). Turning to Eurex, Bunds have now achieved/reclaimed half the down move from January 2nd at 161.48 and the more bullish (or less bearish) mood has also been evident in Schatz options where the 111.90/112.00 1:2 call spread is said to have been bought for zero premium 2k times.

subject: DAILY US OPENING NEWS: Equities stage a modest bounce as Bunds attempt to reclaim Tuesday's lost ground
content:
3rd January 2018

  • Trump tweets that his nuclear button is better than Kim Jong Un’s. N. Korea and S. Korea engage in dialogue
  • European equities rise modestly; positive trading update from Next helps lift other retailers
  • Highlights include the FOMC minutes, US ISM Manufacturing and US auto sales

ASIA

Major Asian indices gained on Wednesday, with investors cheering the strong start to 2018 seen on Wall Street. Miners supported the ASX 200 (+0.2%), which comes amid Australia’s metals and mining index hovered at its best level in 5 years following the rise in metal prices with gold firmly above USD 1300, alongside the recent rally in zinc (zinc hit a 10-year high on Tuesday) . Chinese bourses initially conformed to the upbeat tone before Hong Kong shares ebbed lower (Shanghai Comp +0.6%, Hang Seng +0.1%), with focus also on the PBoC’s actions whereby they strengthened the CNY fix by the most since May 2016, where USDCNY fell below 6.50. Japanese markets remained closed and will reopen on Thursday.

US

No major US stories of note.

EU/UK

German Unemployment Change SA (Dec) -29k vs. Exp. -12k (Prev. -18k, Rev. -20k)

German Unemployment Rate SA (Dec) 5.5% vs. Exp. 5.6% (Prev. 5.6%, Rev. 5.5%)

UK Markit/CIPS Construction PMI (Dec) 52.2 vs. Exp. 52.8 (Prev. 53.1)

GEOPOLITICS

President Trump tweeted that he too has a nuclear button, which is a much bigger and more powerful one than Kim Jong Un's and that his button works. (Twitter)

Officials from North Korea and South Korea have spoken by phone today, according to the South Korean unification ministry. (CNBC)

EQUITIES

European equities have seen a modest bounce-back from yesterday’s losses to trade mostly higher across the board (Eurostoxx 50 +0.4%). The only outlier has been the FTSE 100 (flat) which has been unable to join the party as recent GBP gains have kept potential moves to the upside capped. This also comes in spite of strong performance in UK retail names with Next (+7.1%) top of the leaderboard after an encouraging sales update and raising guidance; subsequently supporting the likes of Marks & Spencer and Associated British Foods (owner of Primark). Elsewhere, tech names are also seen higher in a continuation of sentiment seen on Wall Street yesterday, energy names have also been supported after oil prices hit 2015 highs yesterday.

FX

In FX markets, the DXY has maintained recovery gains above Tuesday’s circa 91.750 3 month low, but the Index has not managed to reclaim the 92.000 handle and therefore looks prime for further losses without any additional support/momentum, which could come via tonight’s FOMC minutes and/or the first official monthly BLS report of the year on Friday. Elsewhere, GBP marginally outperforming as Cable edges towards 1.3600 (no impact from UK construction PMI miss), while Aud/Usd and Nzd/Usd are both off yesterday’s peaks. 0.7850 continues to cap the former pair, and the Kiwi is sitting right on its 200 DMA (0.7105-10) after just failing to reach/breach strong resistance around 0.7132 on Tuesday. Eur/Usd has not really benefited from better than expected German data and remains around 1.2040, with 1.2092 (2017 high). Usd/Jpy contained within another tight range with 112.00 and key chart support just above still being respected, while light offers around 112.40 are noted ahead of bigger sell orders between 112.60-70.

FIXED INCOME

Bunds have reclaimed a bit more lost ground to reach 161.45, with market contacts seeing bids above 161.35 from short term/intraday traders looking for a 50% retracement of Tuesday’s sell-off, which equates to 161.48 – so arguably realised give or take a few ticks. 161.53 represents the next upside pivot, with buy-stops anticipated on a break for a re-test of Tuesday’s opening Eurex peak (161.78), but above forecast German jobs data may have scuppered any prospect of a further rebound. From a bearish chart angle, 161.18 is still on the radar, while Gilts rather belatedly got a boost from their core Eurozone peer to hit 124.44 (+22 ticks vs -16 ticks at worst) and could maintain recovery momentum on the back of another UK PMI miss, although this was not the case after the manufacturing headline confounded expectations yesterday, in fact far from it. The 2 EU benchmarks are currently around 161.35 and 124.35, corresponding 10 year yields approx 0.46% and 1.27% respectively. Peripheral spreads are tighter with Italy leading the way (4.5bps tighter), followed by Spain (4bps), Portugal (1bps) and France (1bps).  

COMMODITIES

In the commodities complex, both WTI and Brent crude futures are seen in modest positive territory ahead of today’s delayed API release. In terms of energy newsflow, things remain light with markets continuing to keep an eye on events in Tehran (albeit Iran denies any impact on their production/export levels). In metals markets, gold has taken a breather from recent advances after hitting 3 ½ month highs with prices broadly tracking movements in the USD. Elsewhere, base metals were also seen lower with some analysts citing adverse weather conditions.

Exxon's Baytown, Texas refinery (the 2nd largest in US) reports emissions from delayed coker unit restart. (Newswires)

subject: UK Trade Minister Fox states that it would be premature for the UK to seek signing up to the TPP Trade Pact but the government are keeping an open mind
EU MID-SESSION UPDATE: Next tops the FTSE following an encouraging sales update. European equities broadly higher. USD clawing back losses
content:

The only outlier has been the FTSE 100 (flat) which has been unable to join the party as recent GBP gains have kept potential moves to the upside capped. This also comes in spite of strong performance in UK retail names with Next (+7.1%) top of the leaderboard after an encouraging sales update and raising guidance; subsequently supporting the likes of Marks & Spencer and Associated British Foods (owner of Primark). subject: Fixed Income: filling gaps before the next major move
content: Bunds have reclaimed a bit more lost ground to reach 161.45, with market contacts seeing bids above 161.35 from short term/intraday traders looking for a 50% retracement of Tuesday’s sell-off, which equates to 161.48 – so arguably realised give or take a few ticks. 161.53 represents the next upside pivot, with buy-stops anticipated on a break for a re-test of Tuesday’s opening Eurex peak (161.78), but above forecast German jobs data may have scuppered any prospect of a further rebound. subject: IOIs on Ireland's May 2028 are in excess of EUR 10bln with guidance seen as mid-swaps +3bps
FX Morning Colour: A degree of Dollar consolidation ahead of Fed minutes
content:
USD

The DXY has maintained recovery gains above Tuesday’s circa 91.750 3 month low, but the Index has not managed to reclaim the 92.000 handle and therefore looks prime for further losses without any additional support/momentum, which could come via tonight’s FOMC minutes and/or the first official monthly BLS report of the year on Friday.

G10 PAIRS

The US Dollar trades narrowly mixed vs major currency counterparts, with Sterling marginally outperforming as Cable edges towards 1.3600, while Aud/Usd and Nzd/Usd are both off yesterday’s peaks. 0.7850 continues to cap the former pair, and the Kiwi is sitting right on its 200 DMA (0.7105-10) after just failing to reach/breach strong resistance around 0.7132 on Tuesday. Eur/Usd has not really benefited from better than expected German data in the form of December unemployment and remains around 1.2040, with 1.2092 (2017 high) still keeping bulls in check, while a decent option expiry at 1.2030 (950 mn) may also be weighing. Usd/Jpy contained within another tight range with 112.00 and key chart support just above still being respected, while light offers around 112.40 are noted ahead of bigger sell orders between 112.60-70. Usd/Cad and Usd/Chf both holding just above big figure levels (1.2500 and 0.9700 respectively), but the Loonie underpinned by firm oil prices and Franc in wake of a firmer than expected Swiss manufacturing PMI.

subject: ASIA-PAC SERVICE HAS NOW FINISHED, PLEASE REVERT BACK TO YOUR ORIGINAL CHANNEL FOR COVERAGE ON THE UK & EUROPEAN SESSION
German new car registration sales up 2.7% in 2017
Short Sterling Futures: trying to stabilise after Tuesday’s declines, and Gilts belatedly
content: UK STIRs are attempting to draw a line under yesterday’s losses, albeit in very thin Liffe trade, but Gilts are not deriving much support (yet) from a bout of consolidation in Bunds that have recovered from their early decline on Eurex to trade up at 161.37 (+9 ticks vs -8 ticks at the low). Fixed and 3 month strips are still in bear re-steepening mode overall and the 10 year bond has been mostly underwater between 124.06-29 vs Tuesday’s 124.22 settlement price. Domestic markets are still awaiting more on Brexit phase 2 and any changes in key Government personnel ahead of the 2nd stage of negotiations. More immediately some attention on the lesser UK PMI (construction) before the main services survey on Thursday.

subject: Ireland IPTs on their May 2028 stand at mid-swaps +5bps
ECB says banks borrowed EUR 317mln at marginal rate & deposited EUR 681.7bln
ECB says banks borrowed EUR 317mln at marginal rate & deposited EUR 681.7bln

European equity movers: Next (NXT LN) +7.4%, Marks & Spencer (MKS LN) +2.5%, Bunzl (BNZL LN) +2.2%, Experian (EXPN LN) +1.9%, ABF (ABF LN) +1.8%, Randstad (RAND NA) +1.3%, Altice (ATC NA) +1.2%, Carillion (CLLN LN) -8.2%
Czech central bank minutes: decision to carry out further rate hikes will depend on macroeconomic developments. A majority would prefer gradual rate hikes
Option expiries of note for today's 10.00am NY cut (1500GMT)
Spanish Unemployment Change (Dec) -61.5K vs. Exp. -58.7K (Prev. 7.3K)
Bunds: on the brink of 161.00/0.50% support/resistance
content: Another tame start for the 10 year German benchmark, but sellers remain in control during early Eurex trade as the core bond future hovers just above nearest tech support in the 161.18 area within a 161.29-20 range vs Tuesday’s 161.28 close. Some (further) uncertainty surrounding the implications of MiFID 2, which officially goes live today, amidst reports that the Deutsche Bourse has been granted a 30 month delay before implantation. In cash terms the 10 year yield is still hovering just below the 0.50% level awaiting supply from Ireland, Spain and France later today and on Thursday, with Italian BTPs regaining a degree of composure after heavy losses and underperformance yesterday. Debt markets also digesting more hawkish ECB vibes about ending QE after the latest extension and of course well aware that the monthly pace of buying is now down to Eur30 bn from Eur60 bn last year. Data-wise the focus falls on German jobs and forecasts for another decline in unemployment.

subject: Officials from North Korea and South Korea have spoken by phone today, according to the South Korean unification ministry
Additional European equity stories post the release of the Daily European equity opening news
content:
Next (NXT LN) - Co. says full price sales in Q4 were up 1.5% Y/Y (Exp. -0.5%). Better than expected results has seen the co. marginally upgrade profit guidance to GBP 718mln-732mln. (Newswires)

Ryanair (RYA LN) - December load factor rose 1ppt to 95%. Rolling annual traffic to December grew 10% to 129mln. (Newswires) 

Wizz Air (WIZZ LN) - December load factor was 87.5% (Prev. 87.3%). (Newswires) 

Electrocomponents (EMC LN) - Co. expects US tax changes will result in a non-cash exceptional tax credit as a result of revaluation of deferred tax balances. (Newswires) 

Carillion (CLLN LN) - FCA has notified the company that it commenced investigation in connection with announcement made by the company between December 2016 and July 2017. (Newswires)

Plus 500 (PLUS LN) - Co. reported record quarterly revenues in Q4 and approximately 246,000 customers joined during 2017. (Newswires)

SFR (SFR FP)/Altice (ATC NA) - SFR says Altice has signed a new partnership deal with Groupe M6 to distribute its channels. (Newswires) 

TERNA (TRN IM) UPGRADED TO HOLD FROM REDUCE AT KEPLER CHEUVREUX

BRENNTAG (BNR GY) DOWNGRADED TO UNDERPERFORM FROM NEUTRAL AT CREDIT SUISSE

EXPERIAN (EXPN LN) UPGRADED TO OUTPERFORM FROM NEUTRAL AT CREDIT SUISSE

SERCO (SRP LN) DOWNGRADED TO UNDERPERFORM FROM NEUTRAL AT CREDIT SUISSE

BUNZL (BNZL LN) RAISED TO OUTPERFORM FROM NEUTRAL BY CREDIT SUISSE

RANDSTAND (RAND NA) RAISED TO OUTPERFORM FROM NEUTRAL BY CREDIT SUISSE

RENTOKIL (RTO LN) CUT TO NEUTRAL FROM OUTPERFORM BY CREDIT SUISSE

HAYS (HAS LN) CUT TO NEUTRAL FROM OUTPERFORM BY CREDIT SUISSE

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS: A group representing airline passengers has taken legal action in a move which could endanger the sale of Air Berlin's Niki unit to IAG (IAG LN)
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

3rd January 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0100CST recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CST all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CST.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CST recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CST ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Major Asian indices gaining on Wednesday, with investors cheering the strong start to 2018 seen on Wall Street. Miners supporting the ASX 200 (+0.2%), which comes amid Australia’s metals and mining index hovering at its best level in 5yrs following the rise in metal prices with gold firmly above USD 1300, alongside the rally in Zinc. Chinese bourses initially conformed to the upbeat tone before Hong Kong shares ebbed lower (Shanghai Comp +0.6%, Hang Seng -0.1%), with focus also on the PBoC’s actions whereby they strengthened the CNY fix by the most since May 2016, where USDCNY fell below 6.50. Japanese markets remain closed and will reopen tomorrow.

FTSE

IAG (IAG LN) - A group representing airline passengers has taken legal action to shift insolvency proceedings for budget airline Niki to Austria from Germany, in a move that could endanger the sale of the Air Berlin (AB1 GY) unit to the Co. (Newswires)

Ryanair (RYA LN) – Co. recently applied for a British air operating licence in a move which may be required to keep its small domestic UK service operating in the event of a hard Brexit. (Newswires)

DAX

Deutsche Boerse (DB1 GY) – CEO has forecast 2018 would be a good year after a turbulent 2017. (Newswires) Separately, Germany has handed the co.’s Eurex a last-minute reprieve from implementing certain MIFID II rules. (FT)

Lufthansa (LHA GY) – The purchase of Alitalia’s operations is a “strategically important target” for the company after the failure to purchase Air Berlin’s Niki unit, according to an unnamed senior manager. (Handelsblatt)  

Merck (MRK GY) – Juniper Pharmaceuticals said its active discussions with the company to extend Crinone Progestorone Gel agreement were progressing well. (Newswires)  

Auto names – Government experts have called for an end to favourable tax treatment of diesel on environmental grounds. (Newswires)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

Innogy (IGY GY) – Co. is examining potential cost cuts across all parts of its business after CEO departure.  

CAC

EDF (EDF FP) – Co. believes that it can build a second nuclear power station to follow Hinkley Point C for up to GBP 5bln less. (Times)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

Elior (ELIOR FP) – Co. said its services had been chosen by Gaumont Pathe Cinemas for the maintenance of their sites in France. (Newswires)  

French companies – The French government’s state privatisation drive is set to accelerate in 2018 as the government prepares to sell large chunks of its holdings to fund ambitious spending plans. (FT)

PAN-EUROPE

Fiat Chrysler (FCA IM) – Co.’s Italian car sales +5.5% Y/Y in 2017. (Newswires)

Akzo Nobel (AKZA NA) – Renier Vree has been appointed as CFO for Specialty Chemicals unit, in effect from March 1st 2018. (Newswires)

SMI

Novartis (NOVN SW) – Kisqali received FDA breakthrough therapy designation for initial endocrine-based treatment in premenopausal women with HR+/HER2 advanced breast cancer. (Newswires)

OTHER SWISS COMPANIES

Schaffner Holding AG (SAHN SW) – Co. said a fire has damaged parts of the Schaffner plant in Thailand; a Schaffner employee and a firefighter were slightly injured. (Newswires)

SCANDINAVIA

Stockman (STCBV FH) – Co. plans to sell a well-known building in Helsinki to cash in on the booming commercial property market and bolster its finances. (Newswires)

US

Although trade was thin, US stocks were on the front foot in the first trading session of the year, with gains being lead by the consumer discretionary sector and tech. Disney was buoyed after reporting that the new Star Wars had hauled in over USD 1bln at the box office. Amazon reported decent Prime delivery numbers. On the other end of the scale, the defensive utility sector was lagging, and financials were lower despite a steeper yield curve. S&P 500 +0.8% at 2696, DJI +0.38% at 24825, NDX +1.76% at 6511.

Top performers: Energy +1.8%, Cons. Disc +1.5%, IT +1.4%

Bottom performers: Utilities -0.9%, Cons. Stap -0.5%, Financials -0.2%

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: Major Asian indices gaining today, with investors cheering the strong start to 2018 seen on Wall Street
content:
• Major Asian indices gaining today, with investors cheering the strong start to 2018 seen on Wall Street
  • Much like 2017, the slump in the USD has continued with the USD-index below 92.00, albeit trading relatively flat in the Asia-Pac session
  • Looking ahead, highlights include German jobs, UK construction PMI, US construction spending, ISM manufacturing PMI, FOMC minutes

ASIA

Major Asian indices gaining today, with investors cheering the strong start to 2018 seen on Wall Street. Miners supporting the ASX 200 (+0.2%), which comes amid Australia’s metals and mining index hovering at its best level in 5yrs following the rise in metal prices with gold firmly above USD 1300, alongside the rally in Zinc. Chinese bourses initially conformed to the upbeat tone before Hong Kong shares ebbed lower (Shanghai Comp +0.6%, Hang Seng -0.1%), with focus also on the PBoC’s actions whereby they strengthened the CNY fix by the most since May 2016, where USDCNY fell below 6.50. Japanese markets remain closed and will reopen tomorrow.

North Korea official says Kim Jong Un gave order to open border hotline between two Korea's at 0630GMT to discuss inter-Korean dialogue in regards to participation in Olympics. (Newswires)

PBoC sets the CNY mid-point at 6.4920 vs. Prev. 6.5079; strongest since May 2016. (Newswires)

PBoC skips open market operations for an 8th straight session; net drain of CNY 90bln vs. Prev. CNY 290bln. (Newswires)

UK/EU

ECB's Nowotny sees a risks of a European stock market bubble. (Newswires)

FX

Much like 2017, the slump in the USD has continued with the USD-index below 92.00, albeit trading relatively flat in the Asia-Pac session. Concerns remain for USD with President Trump retaliating to recent comments made by North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, by stating that his button is bigger, more powerful and actually works. Despite the exchange of words between Washington and Pyongyang, the KRW has continued to strengthen against the USD, which hovers around 2 and half year highs, prompting reports that South Korea may consider measures to boost capital outflows if the currency increases rapidly. Antipodeans, in particular NZD underperformed with the currency circa 10-20pips off the 0.71 handle, having met resistance at 200 DMA of 0.7107, which also represents the 50% Fibonacci retracement of the September/November decline. AUD had dipped also in line with the slight pullback in precious metals, before finding support just north of the 0.78 figure.

COMMODITIES

Precious metals saw a slight pullback in Asian trade with gold slipping some USD 3/oz, silver also took a mild dip to move within close proximity to USD 17/oz. WTI and Brent crude futures very quiet with oil prices trading sideways overnight.

Exxon's Baytown, Texas refinery which is the 2nd largest in US reports emissions from delayed coker unit. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICAL

President Trump states that he too has a nuclear, which is a much bigger and more powerful one than Kim Jong Un's and that his button works. (Twitter)

A ballistic missile launch by North Korea is possible, if not likely, in the coming days, military officials told NBC News. (Newswires)
 

US

TREASURIES: US 10-Year T-Note futures settle 11+ ticks lower at 123-22

The US Treasury Curve bear-steepened in quiet trade, though much of the steepening may have been in sympathy with its major European counterparts following hawkish comments by the ECB’s Coeure over the weekend. Nevertheless, the major curves steepened, with the 2s10s spread up by c.3bps at settlement, 5s30s c.3bps wider, and 2s30s c.5bps steeper.

subject: Swedish Finance Minister reiterates government view of not expecting any major drama in housing prices
ASX 200 200 preliminary close is up by 0.17% at 6071.60
North Korea official says Kim Jong Un gave order to open border hotline between two Korea's at 0630GMT to discuss inter-Korean dialogue
Thai CPI (Dec) Y/Y 0.78% vs. Exp. 0.99% (Prev. 0.99%)
content: Core CPI (Dec) Y/Y 0.62% vs. Exp. 0.65% (Prev. 0.61%)

subject: Source reports note that South Korea are to consider measures to boost capital outflows if KRW increases rapidly
RBNZ updates rules for calculating bank core funding ratios
ASIA MID SESSION UPDATE: Asian equities modestly higher with the ASX 200 supported by miners
content:
Major Asian indices gaining today, with investors cheering the strong start to 2018 seen on Wall Street. Miners supporting the ASX 200, which comes amid Australia’s metals and mining index hovering at its best level in 5yrs following the rise in metal prices with gold firmly above USD 1300, alongside the rally in Zinc. Chinese bourses also conforming to the tone, however the focus had been on the PBoC’s actions whereby they strengthened the CNY fix by the most since May 2016, where USDCNY fell below 6.50. Japanese markets remain closed and will reopen tomorrow.

Much like 2017 the slump in the USD has continued with the greenback below 92.00, albeit trading relatively flat in the Asia-Pac session. Concerns remain for USD with President Trump retaliating to recent comments made by North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, by stating that his button is bigger, more powerful and actually works. NZD underperforms with the currency 20pips off the 0.71 handle, having met resistance at 200 DMA of 0.7107, which also represents the 50% Fibonacci retracement of the September/November decline. The economic calendar is light with only Thai CPI to look out for.

subject: Bank of Thailand December 20th MPC meeting minutes state that member see need to keep accommodative policy
PBoC sets the CNY mid-point at 6.4920 vs. Prev. 6.5079; strongest since May 2016
PBoC skips open market operations for an 8th straight session; net drain of CNY 90bln vs. Prev. CNY 290bln
PRE-MARKET CHINESE STOCK NEWS
content:
SAIC Motor’s (600104 CH) – Vehicle sales rose 6.8% Y/Y to 6.9mln in 2017. (Newswires)

Orient Securities (600958 CH) – Co. raised CNY 11.06bln in A-share private placement. (Newswires)

China Railway Construction (601186 CH) Co. unit signs railway contract worth about CNY 3.53bln in Iran (Newswires)

 

 

Other News

Goldman Sachs sees more risks to the upside than the downside for metals demand in China, playing down concerns of a sharp decline from policy changes. (Newswires)

According to China Securities Times, the PBoC should stabilise CNY rate. (Newswires)

According to Xinhua, China state oil reserves at 37.73mln tons by mid-2017, marking an increase of 13.5%. (Newswires)

subject: President Trump states that he too has a nuclear, which is a much bigger and more powerful one than Kim Jong Un's and that his button works
According to Xinhua, China state oil reserves at 37.73mln tons by mid-2017, marking an increase of 13.5%
Exxon's Baytown, Texas refinery which is the 2nd largest in US reports emissions from delayed coker unit
